title: Ilya Sutskever
content:
{{short description|Transnational computer scientist}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Ilya Sutskever | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=CAN|FRS|size=100%}} |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = 1985–86{{cite web |last1=Simonite |first1=Tom |title=Ilya Sutskever |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/innovator/ilya-sutskever/ |website=MIT Technology Review |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=18 August 2015}} |birth_place = [[Nizhny Novgorod]], Russia{{Cite web |title=Heard It Through the AI {{!}} University of Toronto Magazine |url=https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/alumni-donors/heard-it-through-the-ai-openai-ilya-sutskever/ |access-date=2022-10-09 |website=University of Toronto Magazine |language=en-US}}{{cite web |title=Season 1 Ep. 22 Ilya Sutskever |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fCoavgGZ64Y |website=YouTube |publisher=The Robot Brains Podcast |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=21 September 2021}} |death_date = |death_place = |citizenship = [[Canadians|Canadian]] |nationality = |ethnicity = |fields = [[Mathematics]]
[[Computer Science]] |workplaces = [[University of Toronto]] |alma_mater = [[Open University of Israel]]
[[University of Toronto]]
(B.Sc, M.Sc, Ph.D.) |doctoral_advisor = [[Geoffrey Hinton]] |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = |thesis_title = Training Recurrent Neural Networks |thesis_url = https://www.cs.utoronto.ca/~ilya/pubs/ilya_sutskever_phd_thesis.pdf |thesis_year = 2013 |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Ilya Sutskever''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|FRS}} is a [[computer scientist]] working in [[machine learning]], who co-founded and serves as Chief Scientist of [[OpenAI]].{{cite news |last1=Metz |first1=Cade |title=A.I. Researchers Are Making More Than $1 Million, Even at a Nonprofit |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/technology/artificial-intelligence-salaries-openai.html?action=click&module=RelatedCoverage&pgtype=Article®ion=Footer |access-date=22 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 19, 2018 |language=en}} He has made several major contributions to the field of [[deep learning]]. He is the co-inventor, with [[Alex Krizhevsky]] and [[Geoffrey Hinton]], of [[AlexNet]], a [[convolutional neural network]].{{Cite journal|last1=Krizhevsky|first1=Alex|last2=Sutskever|first2=Ilya|last3=Hinton|first3=Geoffrey E.|date=2017-05-24|title=ImageNet classification with deep convolutional neural networks|journal=Communications of the ACM|volume=60|issue=6|pages=84–90|doi=10.1145/3065386|s2cid=195908774|issn=0001-0782|doi-access=free}} Sutskever is also one of the many authors of the [[AlphaGo]] paper. ==Career== Sutskever attended the [[Open University of Israel]] between 2000 and 2002.{{cite web |title=Neural networking |url=https://thevarsity.ca/2010/10/25/neural-networking/ |website=The Varsity |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=25 October 2010}} In 2002, he moved with his family to Canada and transferred to the [[University of Toronto]], where he then obtained his [[Bachelor of Science|B.Sc]] (2005) in mathematics{{cite web |last1=Johnston |first1=Jessica Leigh |title=A Neural Network for a New Millennium |date=8 December 2010 |url=https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/students/ilya-sutskever-google-phd-fellowship/ |website=University of Toronto Magazine |access-date=14 August 2022}}{{cite web |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |title=Ilya Sutskever |url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/ilya-sutskever/ |website=LinkedIn |access-date=14 August 2022}}and his [[Master of Science|M.Sc]] (2007){{cite thesis |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |title=Nonlinear multilayered sequence models |date=2007 |hdl=1807/119676 |url=https://hdl.handle.net/1807/119676|type=Thesis |language=en}} and [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]] (2012)Multiple sources: *{{cite web |last1=Hinton |first1=Geoffrey |author1-link=Geoffrey Hinton |title=Geoffrey Hinton's former PhD students |url=https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/gradstuphd.html |website=Geoffrey E. Hinton |access-date=14 August 2022}} *{{cite web |title=RAM Workshop |url=http://www.thespermwhale.com/jaseweston/ram/ |website=Jason Weston |access-date=14 August 2022}} *{{cite web |title=Episode 85: A Conversation with Ilya Sutskever |url=https://voicesinai.com/episode/episode-85-a-conversation-with-ilya-sutskever/ |website=Voices in AI |publisher=Gigaom |access-date=14 August 2022}} in [[computer science]] under the supervision of [[Geoffrey Hinton]]. After graduation in 2012, Sutskever spent two months as a postdoc with [[Andrew Ng]] at [[Stanford University]]. He then returned to University of Toronto and joined Hinton's new research company DNNResearch, a [[University spin-off|spinoff]] of Hinton's research group. Four months later, in March 2013, [[Google]] acquired DNNResearch and hired Sutskever as a research scientist at [[Google Brain]].{{cite magazine|url=https://www.wired.com/2013/03/google_hinton/|title=Google Hires Brains that Helped Supercharge Machine Learning|last=McMillan|first=Robert|date=2013-03-13|magazine=Wired|access-date=2019-11-09}} At Google Brain, Sutskever worked with [[Oriol Vinyals]] and Quoc Le to create the [[seq2seq|sequence-to-sequence]] learning algorithm. In 2015, Sutskever was named in [[MIT Technology Review]]'s 35 Innovators Under 35.{{cite web|title=35 Innovators Under 35: Ilya Sutskever|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2015/visionary/ilya-sutskever/}} At the end of 2015 he left Google to become the director of newly founded [[OpenAI]].Multiple sources: *{{cite web|title=OpenAI Blog|date=12 December 2015|url=https://www.openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/|access-date=17 July 2016|archive-date=6 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211006105333/https://openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/|url-status=dead}} *{{cite web|title=Ilya Sutskever's Homepage at University of Toronto|url=http://www.cs.toronto.edu/~ilya/}} *{{cite magazine|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/04/openai-elon-musk-sam-altman-plan-to-set-artificial-intelligence-free/|title=Inside OpenAI, Elon Musk's Wild Plan to Set Artificial Intelligence Free|last=Metz|first=Cade|date=2016-04-27|magazine=Wired|access-date=2019-11-09}} Sutskever was the keynote speaker at NVIDIA NTECH 2018 and [https://aifrontiers.com/ AI Frontiers Conference 2018]. He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 2022.{{Cite web |title=Ilya Sutskever |url=https://royalsociety.org/people/ilya-sutskever-35834/ |access-date=2022-05-12 |website=The Royal Society}} == See also == * [[Oriol Vinyals]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sutskever, Ilya}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Canadian Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Machine learning researchers]] [[Category:Google employees]] [[Category:Canadian computer scientists]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence researchers]] [[Category:Canadian expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:People from Nizhny Novgorod]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] {{Canada-scientist-stub}} {{compu-scientist-stub}}
